SENT.plain: We report on a 4-year-old girl with Angelman syndrome who has an apparent de-novo del(15) (q11q13) originating from a maternally derived chromosome
Her mother had severe brachycephaly, sensorineural hearing loss, speech impediment, and mild ataxia
CT brain scans showed an enlarged foramen magnum in the mother and daughter but magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed no brainstem abnormality in either
This family demonstrates that some Angelman syndrome cases may be dominantly transmitted with variable expression and associated with abnormal or cytogenetically apparently normal chromosome 15
